message_1: Evaluate the limit of the function f(x) = (3x^2 - 2x + 4)/(4x^2 + x) as x approaches infinity.
message_2:
To evaluate the limit of the function f(x) = (3x^2 - 2x + 4)/(4x^2 + x) as x approaches infinity, we can divide both the numerator and the denominator by the highest power of x, which in this case is x^2.

f(x) = (3x^2/x^2 - 2x/x^2 + 4/x^2) / (4x^2/x^2 + x/x^2)

f(x) = (3 - 2/x + 4/x^2) / (4 + 1/x)

As x approaches infinity, the terms with x in the denominator will approach 0:

lim (x -> ∞) (2/x) = 0
lim (x -> ∞) (4/x^2) = 0
lim (x -> ∞) (1/x) = 0

So, the function simplifies to:

f(x) = (3 - 0 + 0) / (4 + 0)

f(x) = 3/4

Therefore, the limit of the function f(x) = (3x^2 - 2x + 4)/(4x^2 + x) as x approaches infinity is 3/4.
